skill.name: pdf
skill.description: Comprehensive PDF manipulation toolkit for extracting text and tables, creating new PDFs, merging/splitting documents, and handling forms. When Claude needs to fill in a PDF form or programmatically process, generate, or analyze PDF documents at scale.
skill.summary: Comprehensive PDF manipulation toolkit for extracting text and tables, creating new PDFs, merging/sp...
skill.author: Anthropic

security_audit.summary: Official Anthropic skill with safe PDF processing utilities. No malicious code detected. Uses standard PDF libraries (pypdf, pdfplumber, reportlab) for legitimate document manipulation tasks.

content.value_statement: Automate PDF workflows including form filling, text and table extraction, document merging/splitting, and PDF generation with enterprise-grade Python libraries.
actual_capabilities: Fill out PDF forms (both fillable fields and non-fillable with annotations)
Extract text from PDFs with layout preservation
Extract tables from PDFs and convert to structured data (CSV, Excel)
Merge multiple PDF documents into one
Split PDFs into individual pages or page ranges
Create new PDFs from scratch with text, tables, and formatting
Rotate, crop, and manipulate PDF pages
Add watermarks and annotations to PDFs
Handle radio buttons, checkboxes, and dropdown fields in forms
Validate form field values and bounding boxes
limitations: OCR for scanned PDFs requires additional setup (pytesseract, pdf2image)
Complex table extraction may require manual adjustment of detection settings
Non-fillable form filling relies on accurate bounding box determination
Some PDF features may render differently across viewers
Performance may degrade with very large PDFs (100+ pages)
Advanced PDF features (3D, multimedia) are not supported

best_practices: Always check if a PDF has fillable fields before attempting manual annotation-based form filling
Validate bounding boxes using validation images when filling non-fillable forms to ensure accuracy
Use pdfplumber for text and table extraction instead of basic pypdf for better layout preservation
For large batch operations, process PDFs in chunks to manage memory usage
Test form-filled PDFs in multiple viewers (Adobe, Preview, Chrome) as rendering can vary
Use high DPI (200-300) when converting PDFs to images for better OCR accuracy
Save original PDFs before applying transformations in case you need to revert
For scanned documents, consider OCR quality and manually verify critical extracted data
anti_patterns: Don't skip the bounding box validation step when filling non-fillable forms - it catches positioning errors
Avoid using basic text extraction for structured data - use pdfplumber's table extraction instead
Don't load entire large PDFs into memory at once - process page by page when possible
Don't assume all PDFs support the same features - test encryption/watermarking on a sample first
Avoid hardcoding font sizes without checking if they fit in the bounding box
Don't ignore intersection errors from the bounding box checker - they indicate overlapping fields

faq.question: How do I know if a PDF has fillable form fields?
faq.answer: Run `python scripts/check_fillable_fields.py <file.pdf>` from the skill directory. This will tell you whether the PDF has fillable fields or requires manual annotation-based filling.

faq.question: Can this skill handle scanned PDFs or image-based PDFs?
faq.answer: Yes, but you'll need OCR. Use pytesseract with pdf2image to extract text from scanned documents. The skill includes examples in reference.md for OCR workflows.

faq.question: What's the difference between fillable and non-fillable form filling?
faq.answer: Fillable forms have defined form fields that can be programmatically filled. Non-fillable forms require visual analysis to determine where text should be placed, then use annotations to add content.

faq.question: How accurate is table extraction from PDFs?
faq.answer: pdfplumber's table extraction works well for PDFs with clear table structures (lines/borders). Complex or poorly formatted tables may require custom extraction settings or manual adjustment.

faq.question: Can I extract specific pages from a PDF?
faq.answer: Yes, you can use pypdf to extract specific page ranges or individual pages, or use command-line tools like qpdf with page range syntax (e.g., `1-5,8,10-end`).

faq.question: What libraries does this skill use?
faq.answer: Primary Python libraries: pypdf (BSD), pdfplumber (MIT), reportlab (BSD), pypdfium2 (Apache/BSD). Command-line tools: poppler-utils (GPL-2), qpdf (Apache). JavaScript options in reference.md: pdf-lib (MIT), pdfjs-dist (Apache).

dependencies: pdfplumber (Python library for text and table extraction)
pdf2image (for converting PDFs to images - optional)
pytesseract (for OCR on scanned PDFs - optional)
permissions: File system read access to input PDF files
File system write access to create output PDFs and temporary files
